Incorrect Option : Option A: Voluntary Axn (Action) and stretch reflex present: This option is incorrect. When the muscle spindle is cut, the sensory input from the spindle is disrupted, leading to the loss of the stretch reflex. As a result, the stretch reflex would not be present. questions.question: Which cells are impacted in multiple sclerosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Oligodendrocytes Explanation: Multiple sclerosis (MS) primarily affects oligodendrocytes , which are responsible for producing and maintaining the myelin sheath in the central nervous system (CNS). In MS, the immune system mistakenly attacks the myelin, leading to demyelination and impairing nerve signal transmission. Incorrect Options: Microglia (Option A) are the resident immune cells of the CNS, and while they may be involved in the immune response in MS, they are not the primary targets. Astrocytes (Option C) support neurons and maintain the blood-brain barrier, and while they may be reactive in MS, they are not directly impacted in the disease. Ependymal cells (Option D) line the ventricles of the brain and produce cerebrospinal fluid, which are not directly involved in MS pathology. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page 92-94.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and spasticity in his right leg. He also notices increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign on the same side. His left leg and upper limbs appear unaffected. MRI of the brain reveals a lesion involving the left motor cortex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Right-sided upper motor neuron lesion. Explanation: The patient's symptoms—progressive weakness, spasticity, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign on the right leg—indicate signs of upper motor neuron (UMN) involvement . UMN lesions typically cause spasticity, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign on the side of the lesion. The MRI shows a lesion in the left motor cortex , which controls motor function on the opposite (right) side of the body due to the crossing of motor pathways in the brain. This reinforces the diagnosis of a right-sided UMN lesion . Parkinson's disease (Option A) : Parkinson's disease primarily affects the basal ganglia and causes symptoms like bradykinesia, resting tremor, and rigidity. It doesn't cause the focal spasticity, hyperreflexia, and Babinski sign observed in this patient. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) (Option B) : ALS affects both upper and lower motor neurons. The patient’s presentation of isolated UMN signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia) and no signs of lower motor neuron involvement (such as atrophy or fasciculations) makes ALS less likely. Multiple sclerosis (MS) (Option C) : MS typically causes relapsing-remitting neurological symptoms with demyelinating lesions in the central nervous system, but the patient’s progressive weakness and focal findings on MRI suggest a more localized lesion, not the typical pattern of MS. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537305/

questions.question: Which molecular motor protein results in spread of the rabies virus from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Dynein Explanation: Dynein is the molecular motor protein responsible for the retrograde transport of the rabies virus along microtubules from the site of inoculation (such as at a peripheral nerve) to the central nervous system (CNS). The virus uses dynein to move towards the cell body of the neuron after entering via the peripheral nervous system. Spread of the rabies virus from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system: The rabies virus spreads from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system (CNS) through retrograde axonal transport . Once the virus enters the peripheral nerves, it binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on the nerve terminals. The virus is then transported along the microtubules of the neuron by the dynein motor protein . Dynein moves the virus towards the cell body of the neuron and eventually to the CNS , where it causes encephalitis. This retrograde transport mechanism is key to the spread of rabies to the brain. Kinesin (Option A) : Kinesins are involved in anterograde transport (moving materials away from the cell body towards the axon terminals), which is not the mechanism used by the rabies virus to spread to the CNS. Actin (Option C) : Actin filaments play a role in cell shape and movement but are not involved in the transport of the rabies virus. Actin-based movement is important for some other types of viral spread, such as with certain enteric viruses. Myosin (Option D) : Myosin is primarily involved in muscle contraction and also in some cell movement processes, but it does not play a role in viral transport, particularly for the rabies virus. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Pg 92

questions.question: Center controlling vomiting?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Area Postrema Explanation: The Area postrema is located in the medulla oblongata and is part of the vomiting center in the brain. It plays a crucial role in detecting toxins or irritants in the blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and triggering the vomiting reflex. This area has a "blood-brain barrier" that is less restrictive, allowing it to respond to circulating substances that may induce vomiting. Vomiting pathway: The vomiting pathway involves a complex coordination between multiple centers in the brain and peripheral structures. Here's a simplified pathway for vomiting (emesis) : 1. Triggering Factors: Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ) : Located in the area postrema in the medulla, it detects toxins, drugs, or metabolic changes in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Gastrointestinal Irritation : Distension, irritation, or inflammation in the stomach, intestines, or esophagus can send signals to the brain. Vestibular System : Motion sickness or vertigo activates the vestibular system in the inner ear, sending signals to the vomiting center. Higher Centers : Emotional stress, pain, or sights/smells (via the cortex and limbic system ) can also induce vomiting. 2. Signal Transmission to the Vomiting Center: Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ) and Gastrointestinal signals : These stimuli are relayed to the vomiting center in the medulla oblongata . The vomiting center integrates signals from multiple sources, including the CTZ , vestibular system , and cerebral cortex . 3. Activation of the Vomiting Center: The vomiting center (located in the medulla oblongata ) coordinates the motor activities required for vomiting, such as contraction of the abdominal muscles and diaphragm, relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter, and retroperistalsis in the stomach. Neurotransmitters involved in this process include serotonin (5-HT) , dopamine , histamine , and acetylcholine . 4. The Vomiting Reflex: Deep inspiration : The diaphragm contracts to create negative pressure. Closure of the glottis : Prevents aspiration of vomitus into the lungs. Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter : Allows the contents of the stomach to move upwards. Contraction of abdominal muscles : Increases intra-abdominal pressure and forces stomach contents into the esophagus. Ejection of gastric contents : Vomiting is completed with the expulsion of stomach contents. Apneustic center (Option A) : The apneustic center, located in the pons , is involved in the regulation of breathing patterns , not vomiting. Pneumotaxic center (Option B) : This center, also located in the pons , helps control the rate and pattern of breathing , not vomiting. Pre-Bötzinger complex (Option D) : Located in the medulla , this area is primarily responsible for generating rhythmic breathing and does not play a direct role in controlling vomiting. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Pg 490 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4230971/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8198651/

questions.question: A patient presented to the ER with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination his vitals were stable, but he could not speak. He had normal handwriting skills, and could understand what was being asked of him to which he responded by nodding. Where could be the lesion for this clinical condition?

options.D: Occlusion of left internal carotid artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Broca’s area Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests a condition known as Broca's aphasia , which is characterized by non-fluent speech . The patient can understand speech and perform normal motor activities (such as handwriting), but cannot speak . Broca's area , located in the left frontal lobe (in the posterior part of the frontal gyrus), is responsible for speech production. A lesion in this area leads to difficulty in speech production , but comprehension remains intact. This explains why the patient can understand what is being asked and respond by nodding, but cannot speak. Brodmann Areas: Definition Numbered regions of the cerebral cortex identified by Korbinian Brodmann, based on neuronal structure and arrangement. Linked to sensory processing, motor control, and cognitive functions. Key Brodmann Areas and Functions Brodmann Area Function 1, 2, 3 Primary somatosensory cortex; processes tactile information. 4 Primary motor cortex; controls voluntary movements. 5, 7 Somatosensory association areas; integrate sensory input. 6 Premotor/supplementary motor areas; plan movements. 17 Primary visual cortex; processes visual data. 18, 19 Visual association areas; advanced visual processing. 22 Wernicke's area; facilitates language comprehension. 44, 45 Broca's area; involved in speech production. Wernicke’s area (Option B) : Lesions in Wernicke’s area , located in the left temporal lobe , cause fluent but nonsensical speech (Wernicke’s aphasia). The patient would have difficulty understanding spoken language, which is not the case here. Primary motor cortex (Option C) : A lesion in the primary motor cortex would cause motor deficits , such as weakness or paralysis, but would not specifically affect speech production in isolation. Occlusion of left internal carotid artery (Option D) : Occlusion of the left internal carotid artery can cause a stroke that might affect various brain regions, but it would likely cause more widespread neurological deficits, including motor and sensory impairments, not just selective speech impairment like in Broca's aphasia.

questions.question: Choose the correct options from the given statements of the enteric nervous system? 1. Vagus is the only afferent from gut 2. Functions independent of brain and SC 3. Myenteric plexus in the lamina propria 4. Exclusively under the influence of nerves 5. Parasympathetic connects enteric to CNS
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 2 Explanation: The enteric nervous system (ENS) is a self-regulating system that can function independently of the brain and spinal cord (SC) , controlling gut motility, secretion, and blood flow. Vagus is not the only afferent from the gut ; the gut also has spinal afferents that carry pain and reflex information. The myenteric plexus (Auerbach's plexus) is located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers , not in the lamina propria . Auerbach plexus between two sets of muscles The ENS is influenced by hormones and local factors , not exclusively by nerves. The parasympathetic nervous system (via vagus and pelvic nerves) connects the ENS to the CNS , modulating its activity. Components of the Enteric Nervous System Component Function Location Myenteric Plexus (Auerbach) Controls motility and peristalsis Between muscle layers Submucosal Plexus (Meissner) Regulates secretion and blood flow In submucosa Autonomy Functions independently but modulated by CNS Entire gut wall 1,2,3 (Option A): Incorrect because the vagus is not the only afferent , and the myenteric plexus is not in the lamina propria . 1,4 (Option B): Incorrect because ENS is not exclusively under neural influence ; hormones and local factors also regulate it. 1,3 (Option C): Incorrect because both vagus-only afferent and myenteric plexus location statements are wrong . Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Pages 262, 263 Wheater Functional Histology. 6th edition. Page 252

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the opposition to passive stretching?
questions.explanation: is velocity-dependent, meaning the resistance to passive movement increases with higher speed or sudden stretching. This directly describes the opposition to passive stretching, as spastic muscles resist being stretched quickly. Incorrect option: Option A. Tone Explanation : Tone refers to the general tension or resistance in a muscle at rest. It can be increased (hypertonic) or decreased (hypotonic) depending on the condition. Tone itself does not specifically describe the opposition to passive stretching but rather the overall state of muscle tension. Option C. Rigidity: Rigidity involves increased resistance to passive movement that is independent of velocity. It is a constant, uniform resistance and is not specifically related to the speed or force of stretching, thus not accurately describing opposition to passive stretching. Option D. Paratonia: Paratonia is characterized by variable resistance to passive movement, which fluctuates between increased and decreased muscle tone. It involves an impaired ability to modulate muscle tone but does not specifically refer to opposition to passive stretching in a consistent manner. Reference: ..

questions.question: What is the connecting structure between Broca's area and Wernicke's area?
questions.explanation: areas of the brain: Broca's area and Wernicke's area. Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals), is involved in the production of speech and language expression. Wernicke's area, located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus, is involved in language comprehension. The arcuate fasciculus serves as a major pathway for communication between these two language areas. It allows for the coordination of language production and comprehension. Damage or disruption to the arcuate fasciculus can result in language deficits, such as conduction aphasia, where there is difficulty repeating words or phrases.

questions.question: Reward centre in the brain is?
questions.explanation: area (VTA). The VTA is a region located in the midbrain, specifically in the mesolimbic pathway. It is known for its role in the brain's reward system, which is involved in the experience of pleasure, motivation, and reinforcement of certain behaviors. The VTA contains dopamine-producing neurons that project to various regions of the brain, including the nucleus accumbens, prefrontal cortex, and amygdala. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter closely associated with reward and pleasure. When the VTA neurons release dopamine in response to rewarding stimuli, it can reinforce behaviors and create a sense of pleasure and motivation. Incorrect options: Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a key structure in the brain involved in emotional processing, particularly in the formation and regulation of fear responses. While it plays a role in processing reward-related stimuli, it is not considered the primary reward center in the brain. The amygdala is interconnected with the reward system and can influence emotional responses to rewarding stimuli, but it does not serve as the central hub for reward processing. Option B. Thalamus: The thalamus is a critical relay station in the brain that processes and relays sensory information to different areas of the cerebral cortex. It serves as a gateway for sensory inputs but is not specifically associated with the reward system or the primary reward center in the brain. Option C. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is primarily involved in memory formation, spatial navigation, and learning. While it is interconnected with other brain regions involved in reward processing, such as the VTA and nucleus accumbens, it is not considered the primary reward center itself. The hippocampus is crucial for memory and contextual associations but is not primarily responsible for the experience of pleasure or motivation related to rewards.

questions.question: What mediates Inverse stretch reflex?
questions.explanation: by the Golgi tendon organs (GTOs). Golgi tendon organs are specialized sensory receptors located in the tendons near the junction of muscles and tendons. When the muscle contracts and applies tension to the tendon, the GTOs are activated. They sense changes in tension and send inhibitory signals to the spinal cord, which in turn inhibits the motor neurons innervating the muscle. This reflex helps prevent excessive tension and potential damage to the muscle and tendon by inhibiting further contraction. Incorrect option: Option B Muscle spindle is incorrect in this context. The muscle spindle is responsible for the stretch reflex, also known as the myotatic reflex, which detects changes in muscle length and initiates a reflex contraction of the muscle. Option C Unmyelinated C fibers are associated with pain perception and are not specifically involved in the inverse stretch reflex. Option D Dorsal Column refers to a pathway in the spinal cord involved in transmitting sensory information related to touch, proprioception, and vibration. It is not directly involved in mediating the inverse stretch reflex.

questions.question: What specific region of the thalamus is associated with the regulation of motor control?
questions.explanation: associated with motor control. It is involved in the transmission of motor signals from the basal ganglia and cerebellum to the motor cortex. The ventrolateral thalamus receives input from the basal ganglia, which is responsible for motor planning and coordination, as well as the cerebellum, which plays a crucial role in motor learning and fine-tuning of movements. The information processed in the VL thalamus is then relayed to the motor cortex, where it contributes to the execution of voluntary movements. Incorrect options: Option B. Ventral posteromedial (VPM) and option (c) Ventral posterolateral (VPL) are regions of the thalamus that are primarily involved in somatosensory processing. They receive sensory information from the body, including touch, temperature, and pain, and relay it to the somatosensory cortex for further processing. Option D. Superior and inferior colliculi are structures located in the midbrain and are involved in visual and auditory processing, respectively. They play important roles in orienting responses to visual and auditory stimuli but are not directly related to motor control.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe increased pain in response to a minor stimulus?
questions.explanation: is a condition where there is an increased sensitivity to painful stimuli, resulting in an exaggerated pain response. It can occur in response to various factors, including tissue injury, inflammation, nerve damage, or certain medical conditions. Hyperalgesia can be categorized into two types: Primary Hyperalgesia: This occurs in the area surrounding the site of tissue injury or inflammation. The affected area becomes more sensitive to painful stimuli, even in response to mild or non-painful stimuli. Secondary Hyperalgesia: This occurs in areas surrounding the primary hyperalgesic zone. It is characterized by an expanded area of increased pain sensitivity beyond the immediate injury site. Hyperalgesia can manifest as an increased intensity or prolonged duration of pain in response to stimuli that would normally be perceived as mildly painful or non-painful. It is believed to involve changes in the peripheral and central nervous systems, including altered neuronal excitability and enhanced pain transmission. Incorrect options: Option A: Hypersensitivity refers to an exaggerated or abnormal response of the immune system to a normally harmless substance, resulting in an allergic or autoimmune reaction. Option C: Causalgia is a type of chronic pain syndrome characterized by severe burning pain, typically following a peripheral nerve injury. Option D: Allodynia refers to the perception of pain in response to a stimulus that is not normally painful, such as light touch or a gentle stroke.

questions.question: Where do the afferent fibers from baroreceptors, responsible for blood pressure regulation, go to?
questions.explanation: nucleus in the medulla oblongata that serves as the primary site for receiving afferent signals from baroreceptors. Baroreceptors, located in the walls of the carotid sinus and aortic arch, sense changes in blood pressure. Afferent fibers from these baroreceptors transmit signals to the NTS, which plays a vital role in regulating blood pressure by modulating autonomic outputs. Incorrect Option: Option A . Nucleus Ambiguous: The Nucleus Ambiguus is a motor nucleus in the medulla oblongata that primarily innervates the muscles involved in swallowing and phonation. It is not directly involved in receiving afferent signals from baroreceptors for blood pressure control. Option B . Rostral-Ventro Lateral Medulla: The Rostral-Ventro Lateral Medulla (RVLM) is a region in the medulla oblongata that plays a crucial role in the regulation of sympathetic outflow and blood pressure. It is involved in the efferent pathway for blood pressure control, but it does not directly receive afferent signals from baroreceptors. Option D. Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla: The Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla (CVLM) is a region in the medulla oblongata involved in the regulation of sympathetic outflow and blood pressure. It primarily serves as an inhibitory center, tonically suppressing sympathetic activity. It is not directly involved in receiving afferent signals from baroreceptors.

questions.question: Maximum area in homunculus signifies
questions.explanation: the homunculus signifies increased preciseness of movements. The larger the area dedicated to a specific body part in the homunculus, the more neural resources are allocated to that body part, indicating a higher level of precision and fine motor control. Incorrect Options: Option A . Low control and skilled movements: This option is incorrect. The maximum area in the homunculus does not signify low control and skilled movements. In fact, the maximum area in the homunculus represents areas of the body that require more precise and skilled movements. Option B . More muscle fibers are present: This option is incorrect. The size of the area in the homunculus does not indicate the number of muscle fibers present. The homunculus is a visual representation of the somatosensory and motor cortices in the brain, where the size of each body part in the homunculus corresponds to the amount of neural representation dedicated to that body part, not the number of muscle fibers. Option D . None of the above: This option is incorrect, as option C (Increased preciseness of movements) is the correct answer.

questions.question: A 40-year-old patient presented to the hospital with a complaint of chronic headache. Upon further investigation, a tumor was identified in the hypothalamus region, which was exerting pressure on the supraoptic nucleus. This structural alteration was found to be affecting hormonal regulation. Which hormone imbalance is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: the supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus and released by the posterior pituitary gland. It plays a key role in regulating water balance by controlling water reabsorption in the kidneys. A tumor in the hypothalamus region that exerts pressure on the supraoptic nucleus can disrupt the production and release of ADH, leading to a condition called diabetes insipidus. In diabetes insipidus, there is an inability to concentrate urine, resulting in excessive thirst and urination. Incorrect Options: Option A - ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone): ACTH is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and regulates the release of cortisol from the adrenal cortex. It plays a role in the body's response to stress and helps maintain proper immune and metabolic functions. A tumor in the hypothalamus region affecting the supraoptic nucleus is unlikely to directly influence ACTH secretion. Option B - GH (Growth Hormone): GH is also produced by the anterior pituitary gland and is responsible for promoting growth and cell reproduction. While hypothalamic tumors can sometimes cause hormonal imbalances, a tumor affecting the supraoptic nucleus is not likely to have a direct impact on GH secretion. Option D - TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone): TSH is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and controls the release of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) from the thyroid gland. It is responsible for regulating the body's metabolism. A tumor in the hypothalamus region affecting the supraoptic nucleus is unlikely to directly influence TSH secretion.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with a peculiar speech. On further evaluation, a defect in the Wernicke's area of his brain is identified. Which of the following condition is associated with the given defect?

options.A: He can make the decision what he speaks
options.C: He is able to understand words and speak properly
options.D: He is understanding language but unable to speak

questions.explanation: in the left hemisphere of the brain's temporal lobe, can result in a condition known as Wernicke's aphasia. Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent speech that lacks meaningful content. The person may produce sentences that are grammatically correct but don't make much sense. This is often referred to as "word salad" and is a hallmark of damage to the Wernicke's area. Incorrect Options: Option A - He can make the decision what he speaks: This option refers to intact executive function and conscious decision-making in speech. If this were the case, the person would have control over their speech and would be able to choose their words appropriately. This is not associated with a defect in the Wernicke's area. Option C - He is able to understand words and speak properly: This option describes intact language comprehension and production abilities. If this were the case, the individual would be able to understand words and their meanings, as well as communicate their thoughts effectively. Wernicke's area is involved in language comprehension, so a defect in this area would likely impact the ability to understand words properly. Option D - He is understanding language but unable to speak: This option describes a condition known as Broca's aphasia. Broca's aphasia is characterized by difficulty in producing speech despite relatively preserved language comprehension. Individuals with Broca's aphasia often struggle to form grammatically correct sentences and may speak in short, telegraphic phrases. This condition is associated with damage to the Broca's area, which is located in the left frontal lobe of the brain, typically in the left hemisphere.

questions.question: Caffeine impairs with sleep by which of the following:

options.D: Activates histamine release and prevent sleep.

questions.explanation: receptors. Adenosine is a neurotransmitter that promotes sleep by slowing down nerve activity. By blocking adenosine, caffeine prevents the brain from sensing sleepiness, thereby promoting wakefulness. Incorrect Options: Option B - Activates locus coeruleus and wakefulness: The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in arousal and wakefulness. While it does play a role in promoting wakefulness, caffeine’s primary mechanism of action is not through direct activation of the locus coeruleus. Option C - No role in maintaining wakefulness: Caffeine is well-known for its role in maintaining wakefulness by counteracting sleep-promoting mechanisms in the brain. Option D - Activates histamine release and prevents sleep: Histamine is involved in promoting wakefulness, but caffeine does not directly cause histamine release. Its effect on sleep is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade rather than histamine pathways. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient is experiencing phantom limb pain after amputation of right limb .What is observed on a PET scan in a patient with phantom limb pain?

options.A: Expansion of right somatosensory fibers for the hand into neighboring areas
options.B: Neighboring fibers of the right somatosensory area extending into the right-hand area

questions.explanation: right-hand area area: After amputation, the brain undergoes cortical reorganization. In this case, the neighboring somatosensory fibers that previously represented adjacent body parts extend into the region that formerly represented the right hand. This reorganization is associated with the perception of phantom limb pain. Incorrect Options: Option A - Expansion of right somatosensory fibers for the hand into neighboring areas: This option suggests that the somatosensory fibers specifically responsible for the right hand expand into neighboring regions. However, it is not the fibers themselves that expand; rather, it is the cortical representation that changes. Option C - Expansion of right sensory cortex: This option implies a general enlargement of the right sensory cortex. However, the expansion is not global; rather, it involves the neighboring cortical areas invading the region corresponding to the amputated limb. Option D - Expansion of left sensory cortex: The left sensory cortex is responsible for processing sensory input from the right side of the body, but this option inaccurately describes the phenomenon. The reorganization occurs in the sensory cortex corresponding to the amputated limb (in this case, the right cortex, which processes left-sided sensations).

questions.question: Which receptor contributes to static 2 point discrimination?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Merkel cell Explanation: Merkel cells are responsible for static two-point discrimination due to their slowly adapting nature and high spatial resolution . Meissner corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that detect light touch and dynamic changes rather than static discrimination. Pacinian corpuscles are specialized for vibration and deep pressure , not fine touch discrimination. All of them is incorrect because only Merkel cells contribute to static two-point discrimination. Anatomy of Cutaneous Mechanoreceptors Receptor Adaptation Function Location Merkel cells Slow-adapting Static touch, two-point discrimination Fingertips, lips, hair follicles Meissner corpuscles Rapid-adapting Light touch, dynamic touch Fingertips, palms, soles Pacinian corpuscles Rapid-adapting Vibration, deep pressure Deep dermis, joints, ligaments Meissner corpuscle (Option B): Incorrect because it responds to dynamic touch rather than static discrimination. Pacinian corpuscle (Option C): Incorrect because it detects vibration and not fine touch resolution. All of them (Option D): Incorrect because only Merkel cells contribute to static two-point discrimination , not the others. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, Pages 599, 600

questions.question: A man was brought to the emergency after suddenly becoming unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sweating Explanation: Physiological Changes in Heat Stroke Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition marked by a core temperature >40°C, leading to CNS dysfunction and multi-organ failure. Key Physiological Changes Hyperthermia : Core temperature rises above 40°C; cellular necrosis occurs at 49°C-50°C, red hot skin. (Option D ruled out) CNS Dysfunction : Symptoms: Confusion, agitation, seizures, coma. Causes: Cerebral hypoperfusion, increased intracranial pressure, and systemic inflammation. Cardiovascular Changes : Tachycardia, hypotension, widened pulse pressure. (Option B ruled out) Distributive shock due to vasodilation and vascular permeability. Metabolic Disturbances : Metabolic acidosis from anaerobic metabolism. Electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyponatremia). Inflammatory Response : Cytokine release (e.g., IL-6) causing endothelial damage, microthrombosis, and DIC. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) : Causes: Rhabdomyolysis, dehydration, reduced renal perfusion. Respiratory Changes : Tachypnea compensates for metabolic acidosis. (Option A ruled out) Kussmaul breathing reflects severe acidosis, indicating critical metabolic derangement. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5964884/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10522494/

questions.question: What causes the stimulation of the Pacinian corpuscle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pressure Explanation: Pacinian Corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that are particularly sensitive to rapid changes in pressure and vibrations of tissues. Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors Structure Function Location Adaptation Pacinian Corpuscle Encapsulated nerve ending Detect tissue vibration or other rapid changes in the mechanical state of tissues Stimulated by rapid local compression of the tissue Immediately beneath the skin and deep in the fascial tissues of the body Adapts in a few hundredths of a second Meissner Corpuscle Elongated, encapsulated nerve ending of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber Sensitive to movement of objects over the skin and low-frequency vibrations crucial for spatial location discernment of touch sensations Nonhairy skin, particularly abundant in fingertips and lips. Adapts in a fraction of a second Hair End Nerve fiber entwined at the base of each hair Detects : Movement of objects on the body surface or Initial contact with the body Hairy skin Adapts readily Specialized mechanoreceptors Superficial Superficial Deep Deep Discriminatory touch, Stroking Texture, Edges, Braille Pressure, Vibration Sustained pressure Rapidly adapting Slowly adapting Rapidly adapting Slowly adapting

questions.question: What findings would be observed in a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury due to a road traffic accident, whereby the fracture fragment has penetrated the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract?

options.A: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
options.B: Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
options.D: Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Absence of Ipsilateral arm Proprioception Explanation: The dorsal column tract of the spinal cord is responsible for proprioception, vibration sensation, and fine touch. Pathway Sensory Modalities Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscal System Touch: Provides precise localization and fine gradations of intensity. Vibration: Detects rapid changes in stimulus through phasic sensations. Proprioception: Contributes to the sense of body position and movement. Pressure: Allows for the perception of fine degrees of pressure intensity. Dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway: Pathway Sensory receptors → Spinal cord (dorsal roots) → Brain (somatosensory cortex) Neurons First-order neurons Originate in mechanoreceptors, and enter spinal cord via dorsal roots Pseudo-unipolar neurons with cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion Split into medial and lateral branches: Medial branch: Travels up dorsal column to brain Lateral branch: Synapses in dorsal horn, forming local reflexes, spinocerebellar tracts Fibers from lower thoracic, sacral, and lumbar regions (T7-T12, L, S) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus gracilis Fibers from cervical and upper thoracic regions (C, T1-T6) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus cuneatus (Option C) Second-order neurons Synapse in dorsal medulla (cuneate nucleus for upper body, gracile nucleus for lower body) Cross to opposite brain stem side, travel to thalamus (medial lemniscus) Third-order neurons Synapse in thalamus (ventrobasal complex) Project to somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus, lateral parietal cortex)

questions.question: The patient exhibits symptoms depicted in the image provided below. Shows the site of the lesion Experiences decreased proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the affected side. Has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Brown Sequard syndrome Explanation: Brown-Séquard syndrome is a condition resulting from a hemisection (or lesion) of the spinal cord . The symptoms described align with the clinical presentation of this syndrome: Decreased proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the same side as the lesion (due to damage to the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway , which crosses at the medulla). Loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion on the contralateral side (due to damage to the spinothalamic tract , which crosses immediately at the level of the spinal cord). Weber’s syndrome

questions.question: In case a small pain stimulus causes more pain, it is called?
questions.explanation: increased sensitivity to painful stimuli, resulting in an exaggerated pain response. It can occur in response to various factors, including tissue injury, inflammation, nerve damage, or certain medical conditions. Criteria Hyperalgesia (Option C) Allodynia (Option D ruled out) Definition Severe pain from a stimulus that normally causes pain Pain from a stimulus that normally wouldn't cause pain, Sensitivity Both increases sensitivity of nociceptive afferent fibers Cause Primary hyperalgesia: Excessive sensitivity of the pain receptors. Eg : Extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin (results from sensitization of pain receptors due to local tissue products like histamine, prostaglandins) Secondary hyperalgesia: It is the facilitation of sensory transmission . Eg: Lesions in the spinal cord or thalamus The exact cause is unknown. Likely involves error in neuronal conduction. Eg:Painful sensation from a light touch which is never painful Association Both types of pain is seen in neuropathic pain and causalgia (severe burning pain in a specific part of the body) (Option B ruled out) Hypersensitivity (Option A): It refers to an exaggerated or abnormal response of the immune system to a normally harmless substance, resulting in an allergic or autoimmune reaction. This option is incorrect. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page no:618 Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, Edition 26, page no:163 G K Pal Edition 1 page no:1022 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537129/

questions.question: What specific region of the thalamus is associated with the regulation of motor control?
questions.explanation: region of the thalamus that is closely associated with motor control. It is involved in the transmission of motor signals from the basal ganglia and cerebellum to the motor cortex. Thalamic Nucleus Function Ventral Posterolateral (VPL) (Option C ruled out) Relays somatosensory information from the body to the primary somatosensory cortex Ventral Posteromedial (VPM) (Option B ruled out) Relays somatosensory information from the face to the primary somatosensory cortex Lateral Geniculate (LGN) Relays visual information from the optic tracts to the primary visual cortex Medial Geniculate (MGN) Relays auditory information from the inferior colliculus to the primary auditory cortex Ventral Anterior (VA) Contributes to motor control by receiving input from the basal ganglia Ventral Lateral (VL) (Option A) Contributes to motor control by receiving input from the cerebellum Anterior (AN) Involved in memory, emotion, and regulation of the limbic system Intralaminar Nuclei Involved in arousal, attention, and modulation of pain perception Superior and inferior colliculi (Option D): They are structures located in the midbrain and are involved in visual and auditory processing, respectively . They play important roles in orienting responses to visual and auditory stimuli but are not directly related to motor control. Reference: G.K Pal - Comprehensive textbook of medical physiology, 1st Edition- Page 1031, 1181, 1208

questions.question: In a young patient who experienced a head injury from a road traffic accident, his family reports a change in his behavior. They describe him as being excessively curious and constantly touching objects. He also exhibits rapid forgetfulness and attempts to put various things in his mouth, including plates. Additionally, they have observed him squeezing his genitals. Based on these symptoms, which structure is most likely to be affected in this patient?

options.A: Gray matter around the aqueduct of Sylvius

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Amygdala Explanation: The symptoms described in the patient, such as excessive curiosity, rapid forgetfulness, inappropriate behavior (putting things in his mouth), and genital squeezing, are suggestive of Klüver-Bucy syndrome . This syndrome is associated with damage to the amygdala , which plays a central role in emotion regulation and behavior. The amygdala’s dysfunction leads to behaviors like hypersexuality, hyperorality (putting objects in the mouth), and changes in emotional responses. The amygdala is an almond-shaped structure located in the temporal lobe, just beneath the uncus. It is a complex and diverse structure composed of around 13 nuclei, which are interconnected through extensive internuclear and intranuclear pathways. These nuclei are functionally organised into five major groups: basolateral nuclei, cortical-like nuclei, central nuclei, other amygdaloid nuclei, and the extended amygdala. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, Pg 749-751

questions.question: A person is having increased sexual activity ,increased appetite, anger and no fear, which is the structure injured?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Hypothalamus Explanation: The hypothalamus is a crucial brain structure that regulates various physiological functions, such as hunger, thirst, sexual behaviour, and emotions. It plays a central role in maintaining homeostasis and coordinating the body's responses to external stimuli. Injury to the hypothalamus can result in changes in behaviour, including heightened sexual activity, increased appetite, and altered emotional responses. Amygdala (Option A): The amygdala plays a role in processing emotions, particularly fear and aggression. If there were an injury to the amygdala, it might result in altered emotional responses, including decreased fear and potentially increased aggression, but it would not likely be the primary cause of increased sexual activity and appetite. Thalamus (Option B): The thalamus serves as a relay center for sensory and motor signals. It is not directly responsible for regulating emotions, sexual activity, appetite, or fear responses. Cingulate Gyrus (Option C): The cingulate gyrus is involved in emotional processing and regulation, but it is not the primary structure responsible for increased sexual activity, increased appetite, anger, and decreased fear

questions.question: Corticospinal tract crosses at?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Lower medulla Explanation: The corticospinal tract decussates (crosses) at the lower medulla , specifically at the pyramidal decussation . This crossing allows for the contralateral (opposite side) control of voluntary motor movements. Midbrain (option A) : The corticospinal tract does not cross at the midbrain. While the midbrain is involved in motor control, the decussation occurs lower in the brainstem. Pons (option B) : The corticospinal tract does not decussate at the pons. The pons plays a role in the communication between the cerebrum and cerebellum but not in the decussation of the corticospinal tract. Upper medulla (option C) : The crossing of the corticospinal tract happens in the lower medulla , not the upper medulla. The upper medulla is the region just above the pyramidal decussation, where the fibers begin to descend before crossing over. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg. 238

questions.question: What is the duration of short-term memory?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 30-300 seconds Explanation: Short-term memory (STM), also called working memory, is the brain's temporary storage system used for immediate tasks such as reasoning or learning. It retains information for a brief period, typically lasting 30 to 300 seconds (0.5 to 5 minutes). Beyond this timeframe, information either decays or transfers to long-term memory if rehearsed or encoded. Short-term memory: Short-term memory retains information for durations ranging from seconds to several hours. The ventral hippocampus , specifically the CA1 region, is responsible for short-term memory. Through rehearsal or repetition, short-term memories can be consolidated into long-term memories. Long-term memory: Long-term memory retains information for years or even a lifetime. The neocortex serves as the centre for long-term memory storage. Incorrect Options: 3-6 hours (Option A): This duration is associated with long-term memory consolidation , not short-term memory. Short-term memory is transient and does not last for hours without active rehearsal. 12-18 hours (Option B): This duration pertains to retained information in long-term memory or residual effects of memory retention after learning. Short-term memory operates on a much shorter timescale. 3-4 seconds (Option D): This duration corresponds to sensory memory , particularly echoic (auditory) or iconic (visual) memory, which lasts only a few seconds before decaying. It is not the same as short-term memory. Reference: Guyton & Hall Textbook of Physiology Edition 14th, page 736-738 2. Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Pg. 282

questions.question: Weber-Fechner law relates the magnitude of sensation to ___________.
questions.explanation: felt is proportionate to the log of the intensity of the stimulus. I = K log (S/So) Where: So: Threshold amplitude K: Constant S: Stimulus strength I: Intensity of sensation Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: In the homunculus, which of the following body parts exhibits the highest degree of representation ?
questions.explanation: based on the fact that the size of the cortical receiving area for impulses from a particular part of the body is proportionate to the use of the part. The more the area of a body part, the more the receptors for carrying out function carried out by those body parts. The homunculus is mainly covered by hand, face, and tongue, which carries out precise movements. Therefore, the part of the body responsible for precise movements occupies the maximum space in the homunculus. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area.
questions.explanation: profound analgesia. These nuclei are serotonergic and end in the dorsal horn in the spinal cord. The Pain-carrying fiber (Adelta/C) creates a synapse with a second-order neuron, which brings the sensation up to the level of the thalamus and perceives pain. Serotonin activates enkephalin-producing interneurons and inhibits the pain pathway, acting at the levels of presynaptic (1st order) and postsynaptic neurons (2nd order). Other areas responsible for analgesics are RVLM (Rostral Ventrolateral Medullary Region) and Locus coeruleus region secretes norepinephrine. Incorrect Options: Option B - Corticospinal tract: The corticospinal tract is primarily involved in voluntary motor control and does not play a direct role in pain relief. Option C - Medial lemniscus: The medial lemniscus is a pathway in the central nervous system that carries sensory information related to touch, vibration, and proprioception. Option D - Medial longitudinal fasciculus: The medial longitudinal fasciculus is a neural pathway involved in coordinating eye movements and connecting various brainstem nuclei. Reference: .

questions.question: What are the factors that can lead to a person drinking water as a result of the stimulation of the thirst mechanism ?
questions.explanation: Dehydration, hemorrhage, and vomiting will lead to loss of isotonic fluid from the blood leading to increased renin secretion. Renin leads to an increase in the concentration of angiotensin 2 (Ag ll), which acts as a stimulus for the subfornical nucleus (SFO) osmoreceptor center in the anterior hypothalamus. Incorrect Options: Option A, B & C are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is Prosopagnosia?
questions.explanation: blindness , is a neurological disorder characterized by the inability or difficulty to recognize and identify familiar faces, including those of friends, family members, and even one's own face. It is caused due to lesion in the inferior temporal lobe. People with prosopagnosia may have normal vision and intellectual abilities but struggle specifically with facial recognition. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes

options.A: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
options.B: Pain and temperature lost on the same side

options.D: Only pain lost on the same side

questions.explanation: due to the hemisection of the spinal cord. It is characterized by: On the side of the lesion: Loss of touch, proprioception, vibration, and tactile discrimination are lost due to damage to the dorsal column pathway. On the opposite side: Pain and thermal sensations are lost due to damage to the spinothalamic tract. Incorrect Option: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation. questions.question: Which specific neurotransmitter is accountable for causing dilation of the small intestine in a forward direction?
questions.explanation: neurotransmitter released when the cholinergic neuron from the myenteric plexus moves in the anterograde direction of the peristalsis. It acts as a relaxant on smooth muscles in the proximal segment of the segment containing chyme, resulting in relaxation of the proximal segment of the chyme and movement of the content towards the rectum. Incorrect Options: Option B - Acetylcholine : Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter released by cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction of the peristalsis and results in the contraction of the smooth muscle. Option C - Substance P : Substance P is a neurotransmitter that is released when cholinergic neuron from the myenteric plexus moves in the retrograde direction of the peristalsis and results in the contraction of the smooth muscle. Option D - Serotonin : Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that is secreted by the gastric epithelial cells in response to stretch due to food. It is responsible for the activation of myenteric plexus resulting in coordinated movements in peristalsis. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the effect of a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons ?

options.A: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
options.B: Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
options.C: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
options.D: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.explanation: lemniscus at the level of the pons would lead to damage in the dorsal column pathway as the second order neurons pass from it to reach thalamus. The second order neurons arise from nucleus gracilis and cuneatus of the contralateral side.. These are responsible for the transmitting the following sensations: Fine touch Vibration Proprioception Tactile localization Tactile discrimination Stereognosis So, damage to the dorsal column pathway at medial lemniscus will result in loss of proprioception and tactile on the opposite side. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the options accurately describes decorticate rigidity ?

options.A: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia.
options.B: Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs.
options.D: It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs.

questions.explanation: to the cerebral cortex results in decorticate rigidity, characterized by upper extremity flexion at the elbow and increased extension in the lower extremities. The flexion of the upper extremities is explained by rubrospinal excitation of flexor muscles, while the hyperextension of the lower extremities is due to dysfunction in the medulla, resulting in increased activity of motoneurons that facilitate stretch reflexes. Dysfunction in the descending pathways that control muscle tone and movement. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of decerebrate rigidity according to the Herrington classification ? γ efferent neuron

options.A: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
options.B: Increase in the rate of discharge of the
options.C: Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
options.D: Mid Collicular lesion can lead to decerebrate rigidity

questions.explanation: affects the extensor muscles of the limbs , leading to the characteristic posture of rigid extension. It does not affect all the muscles of the body equally . According to the Herrington classification, decerebrate rigidity is a form of abnormal muscle tone that occurs due to damage or dysfunction in the medulla resulting in increased activity of motoneurons that facilitate stretch reflexes. Facilitation of stretch reflexes occurs due to two mechanisms: Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool in general. Increased rate of γ motor neuron discharge. Producing a mid-collicular lesion in an experimental animal results in decerebration. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which receptors are responsible for mediating the stretch reflex among the options provided ?
questions.explanation: They detect changes in muscle length and initiate a reflex response that leads to muscle contraction. questions.question: What is the name of the first neuron in the optic pathway ?
questions.explanation: from photoreceptor cells and transmit them to ganglion cells. Incorrect Options: Option B - Ganglion cells: Ganglion cells are the second-order neurons. They receive signals from bipolar cells and transmit these signals along their axons, forming the optic nerve to the lateral geniculate body. Option C - Cells in lateral geniculate body: Lateral Geniculate body is the third-order neuron. The optic nerve fibers synapse at the LGN in the thalamus. Option D - Rods and Cones: These cells are photoreceptors and they are end receptors. They detect light and convert it into electrical signals. Reference: Prepladder Notes
